title: 7 Natural Remedies for Insomnia
author: Caroline Igo
description: CBD, tea and other natural remedies insomniacs may like over melatonin.
cleaned_text: 7 Natural Remedies for Insomnia CBD, tea and other natural remedies insomniacs may like over melatonin. Quality rest makes it possible to carry out your day-to-day functions. It strengthens your immune system, boosts [heart health](https://www.cnet.com/health/sleep/the-connection-between-sleep-blood-pressure-and-heart-health/), repairs muscle tissue, promotes memory and knowledge retention, and even bolsters your [mental health](https://www.cnet.com/health/mental/4-things-that-will-boost-your-mental-health-without-paying-for-therapy/). Despite sleep being so essential to our overall well-being, [one-third of adults have insomnia symptoms](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/insomnia-what-you-need-to-know-as-you-age). And if you're one of them, getting that all-important shut-eye may seem impossible at times. Even [the classic tricks](/health/sleep/6-tried-and-true-tips-to-fall-asleep-faster/), like reading in another room and turning off blue light, can prove ineffective. Before you know it, sleep deprivation turns you into a crankier, dazed, unhealthy version of yourself. When you search the internet for natural remedies for sleep disturbance, melatonin supplements are usually the first recommendation. However, if you're [skeptical about sleep supplements](/health/sleep/melatonin-can-make-you-groggy-try-these-3-sleep-supplements-instead/), struggle with [the side effects](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/melatonin-side-effects) or would just rather not take any pills that may leave you groggy in the morning, here are seven natural sleep aids and techniques to help ease your insomnia. For more tips on better sleep, check out the [best food to eat before bed](/health/sleep/7-foods-to-help-you-sleep-better/), [how to take a coffee nap](/health/sleep/heres-how-to-use-a-coffee-nap-to-boost-your-energy-levels/) and [how to create the perfect sleep playlist](/health/sleep/how-to-create-the-perfect-sleep-playlist/). Use CBD oils, gummies or creams CBD, also known as cannabidiol, is derived from hemp plants. CBD is a [safe and effective](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28861514/) [treatment for insomnia](https://www.sleepassociation.org/sleep-treatments/cbd/) that contains almost no THC, the substance in marijuana that alters one's mental state. Many studies suggest that CBD is very [effective in promoting sleep](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32774241/) and [decreasing anxiety](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26341731/). It comes in many forms, such as oils and lotions. Use before bed to promote sleepiness and relaxation. Brew a hot cup of herbal tea Brewing tea is an ancient practice. [Chamomile](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30000867/), [valerian root](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Valerian-HealthProfessional/) and [magnolia](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5365644/) tea are all natural remedies for anxiety, stress and insomnia. Drink a cup of one of these [herbal teas](/health/mental/best-teas-for-anxiety-and-stress/) at least an hour to two hours before bed -- this gives you time to relax, enjoy the tea and use the bathroom before lights off. Be sure to look at the nutrition label to make sure no caffeine has been added to the ingredients. Put a drop of lavender oil on your pillow One of the more popular household remedies -- essential oils. If tea is not your favorite way to relax before bedtime, floral and herbal [fragrances are good ways to aid sleep](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31556690/). Some popular essential oils for sleep are lavender, chamomile, and bergamot. Essential oils should never be ingested, but you can put a little drop on your pillow at night. You can also [diffuse](/health/best-essential-oil-diffuser/) essential oils into the air or use dried lavender to make a tea. Put a few drops of this lavender essential oil in a diffuser to help you drift off. You can also dilute in water and spray a little on your pillow. Drink tart cherry juice Sour cherry juice from tart cherries can [increase melatonin production](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22038497/) in those who consume it before bedtime. In the same study, the group who drank the cherry juice spent more time in bed, asleep and achieved higher overall sleep efficiency. This suggests that tart cherry juice has potential to aid insomnia. Try dried passionflower or extract oil Not to be confused with passionfruit -- passionflower is a fast-growing vine that produces vibrant flowers. Not only is the plant beautiful, it can even help you fall asleep either by herbal tea or extract oil. A recent study concluded that passionflower has [the potential to treat insomnia](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31714321/). However, it is not recommended for those who are pregnant. Make sure you're getting enough magnesium [Magnesium](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Magnesium-HealthProfessional/), a powerful nutrient, is responsible for regulating hundreds of processes in the body -- including [sleep](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23853635/). Magnesium is found naturally in foods such as nuts and seeds, spinach, soy milk, yogurt and whole grains. Try lightly snacking on foods high in magnesium an hour or two before bed. If you believe that you aren't getting enough [magnesium in your diet](/health/nutrition/adding-magnesium-to-your-diet-what-you-should-know/) and suspect it could help your sleep, try adding a [supplement](/health/nutrition/5-best-magnesium-supplements/). Practice yoga and meditation before bedtime Strenuous exercise before bed is [not always a good idea](https://www.health.harvard.edu/staying-healthy/does-exercising-at-night-affect-sleep), but practicing light [yoga](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6393899/) or [meditation](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/mindfulness-meditation-helps-fight-insomnia-improves-sleep-201502187726) before bed has been linked to decreased insomnia and better sleep. Go through [simple yoga poses](/health/sleep/if-you-struggle-to-fall-asleep-these-yoga-poses-can-help/), such as cat-cow, forward fold or bridge, focusing on your breath and feeling the stretch. There are also many self-guided [meditation apps](/health/sleep/best-meditation-apps/) available. For more health tips, [here's how to create the ideal environment for better sleep](/health/sleep/how-to-create-the-perfect-environment-for-better-sleep/) and [how to sleep cooler without air conditioning](/health/sleep/no-air-conditioner-try-these-hacks-to-sleep-cooler-without-it/).
